unnormalised: Managing schedules in the Indian office context can be quite the juggling act, right? Trying to coordinate meetings across time zones with colleagues in the US or Europe while keeping in mind everyone's chai breaks and lunch timings can feel like a full-time job. We’ve all been there, frantically emailing “Pls confirm availability for mtg on 22/08 at 3 PM IST,” hoping for a quick response before another fire drill pops up.
normalised: Managing schedules in the Indian office context can be quite the juggling act, right? Trying to coordinate meetings across time zones with colleagues in the U-S or Europe while keeping in mind everyone's chai breaks and lunch timings can feel like a full-time job. We’ve all been there, frantically emailing “Please confirm availability for meeting on twenty second august at three P-M I-S-T,” hoping for a quick response before another fire drill pops up.

unnormalised: One major challenge is definitely accounting for Indian Standard Time (IST), which is GMT+5:30. It's easy to forget when setting up calls with the London office, leading to someone dialing in at 2:30 AM their time! I once accidentally scheduled a client call for 11:30 PM IST, only to realize my mistake when I got a frantic call at 11:15 PM from a very sleepy client. Lesson learned: double-check, triple-check those time zones!
normalised: One major challenge is definitely accounting for Indian Standard Time (I-S-T), which is G-M-T plus five hours thirty minutes. It's easy to forget when setting up calls with the London office, leading to someone dialing in at two thirty A-M their time! I once accidentally scheduled a client call for eleven thirty P-M I-S-T, only to realize my mistake when I got a frantic call at eleven fifteen P-M from a very sleepy client. Lesson learned: double-check, triple-check those time zones!

unnormalised: Then there's the whole world of Indian holidays to consider. No one wants to schedule a crucial presentation on 15/08 (Independence Day) or during the Diwali week. Office calendars often mark these, but it's always a good idea to double-confirm with your team, especially if you're relatively new to the team. I had a team lead once prepone a meeting on Holi, thinking no one would mind. Safe to say, the turnout was… minimal.

unnormalised: Another thing that can throw a wrench in the works is the "Indian Stretchable Time," or IST as some jokingly call it. Punctuality isn't always strictly adhered to, and a meeting scheduled for 10:00 AM might realistically start around 10:15 AM. Building in a little buffer time can be a lifesaver. And don't be surprised if someone shows up 5 mins late citing "traffic" – it’s practically a national excuse!

And don't be surprised if someone shows up five minutes late citing "traffic" – it’s practically a national excuse!

unnormalised: Tech tools can definitely help. Google Calendar, Microsoft Outlook, and apps like Doodle can be really useful for finding mutually convenient times. Setting reminders well in advance is also crucial. A notification an hour before the meeting, another 15 mins before – overkill? Maybe, but it beats having to explain to your boss why you missed that important client call scheduled for 14:00 hrs.

unnormalised: Ultimately, successful scheduling in an Indian office requires a blend of careful planning, cultural awareness, and a healthy dose of flexibility. Remember to account for time zones, holidays, potential delays, and everyone's favorite chai breaks. With a little bit of effort and a lot of communication, you can keep your schedule (and your sanity) intact.
